review_title: A Great Place to Learn While Working
job_title: Learning and Engagement Specialist in Lehi, UT
pros:
If you are working in the Learning and Engagement Department, you will find many opportunities to learn. You get the chance to expand your knowledge and apply it. Some examples:
*Learn entomology while surrounded by invertebrates at Butterfly Biosphere. You learn to handle exotic insects and can even volunteer to work in an entomology laboratory!
*Learn paleontology and geology at the Museum of Ancient Life. Similar to Butterfly Biosphere, you can work on fossil preparation and research! You can hold a piece of earth's history in your hands and know that you were one of the people that uncovered it. Pretty incredible.
*Learn plants while conducting tours at Ashton Gardens (mainly during the Tulip Festival)
*Learn many forms of play and keeping positive at the Museum of Natural Curiosity
*Learn animal handling and facts at the farm

And this is just venue work. There are dozens of programs you can get involved in to learn even more (3D printing, lasercutting, woodshop at the Makerspace; earthquake science in school outreach; music and early childhood psychology in the many early childhood programs)!

The other advantage? You don't have to learn anything if you don't want to! The inquiry-driven facilitation process allows you to simply ask questions and play without worrying about being the smartest person in the room. They hire people from every walk of life because the balance of knowledge, play, and inquiry shouldn't be the same from employee to employee, and they know that. They hire high schoolers (18+), college students, college graduates, people with normal hair, people with crazy hair, people with no hair, single people, married people, moms, dads, grandparent semi-retirees up to the age of 72. They value a full spectrum of experiences and what those experiences can bring.
cons:
1. Pay. They hire mainly part-time for pay that is equal to or less than most of the food and retail places surrounding them. It is very difficult to get fulltime, and even at this level with massively expanded responsibility, raises do not keep pace with inflation the last time I checked. 

2. Professional respect. It is astonishing how often someone will say, "You have the funnest job! (pardon the grammar, but that IS what they say)" and when told about how we're hiring--mind you, this is while you are currently working with their kids in a competent and professional manner--will reply, "Oh, yeah, but I have a REAL job," or better yet, the college student saying "I'm GOING to get a REAL job when I graduate." They might assume the first point above, as yes, they do not give big boy pay, but the fact that they leave it to interpretation shows an alarming failure in diplomacy. Of course, anyone on the low-pay front lines--retail, food industry, customer service--would already relate to this I'm sure, without having fun at their job. So, this is hardly a distinct con for those starting out. And growing a thick skin and a permanent smile might itself be a pro?

3. Mobility. This ties in with the first point. Higher level management directors and such have to work insanely hard to get their positions, insanely hard to keep them, and are not given industry competitive salaries. So, you have to have passion, willingness to sacrifice, and willingness to stay where you are, possibly forever. For some, that's great, we've had some part-timers stay for over a decade. That said, it acts as a great springboard to get jobs in the museum and education industry that do have higher mobility, as the skills mentioned in the pros do count for something.

pros:
This place can be very rewarding when you are playing with families and genuinely seeing the great time they are having. Being able to make a difference with their day, regardless of how big or small, is incredibly fulfilling. 

It even reminds you that even as an adult, you can still learn and have fun while doing it. You may be able to rediscover your passions which will help you with your regular job duties.
cons:
The communication and responsibilities can be tough. Some days you won't know what is going on until last minute which increases the stress amongst the employees. Yes this can happen with many companies, but if you want to ensure that empathy is spread towards customers, it's important for the employees to have that towards each other as well.

Scheduling can be incredibly difficult especially if you are not used to having it steady. You are required to have your days requested off within a certain amount of time and they are supposed to have your schedule done weeks in advance. What makes it difficult is when your schedule still isn't cemented even after the time it's scheduled. I get that emergencies happen, but sometimes it feels that it isn't as 2 sided.

review_title: Amazing job building experience, culture needs help
job_title: Educational Program Coordinator in Lehi, UT
pros: Great entry level position to give you experience in educational program management. Opportunities to grow, lead, fail forward and be knee deep in museum standard best practices. Incredibly fun environment and  be a part of a large community organization. Flexibility in work hours to make a lot of your own schedule. Management trusts and expects coordinators to do their jobs. Micromanagement is nonexistent. Working with guests is amazing.
cons: Lack of support and critical, direct feedback from management. Salaried position with poverty level pay (school teachers make more) and minimal benefits. Gossip runs rampant. Education department is seen as cost center by senior management and not taken seriously.

review_title: Poor Management, Wanted Out Right Away
job_title: Guest Service Team Member in Lehi, UT
pros: Fun institution, I'd recommend visiting but DO NOT work there. The only pro I can think of are the employee benefits like getting into the venue you work at for free. I was hired to work at the Gardens and wasn't scheduled there ONCE. The managers seem fun and nice at first, but it's all fake because they will tear you apart with their judgement.
cons:
Contradicting and arbitrary dress code rules, inefficient enforcement of the rules, poor communication, managers were immature and dramatic, poor scheduling, very gossipy, fake nice, judgemental, Mormon run company, VERY conservative... Like they'll get you in trouble if you tuck your shirt in and then they'll talk about you behind your back. And I hadn't even worked there a full month yet! 

Not the safe and loving environment I hoped for.

review_title: Great Venues, Neat Opportunities, Disappointing Management
pros: The venues are wonderful, the reputation of Thanksgiving Point is strong and generally positive, and there is always something new and exciting going on
cons: Employees do not feel valued, and are not disciplined properly for misbehavior, resulting in significantly lowered morale and a difficulty trusting and relying on fellow team members who have no incentive or reason to do their jobs well (since no consequences seem to come of it).

review_title: The perks make it worth it
pros: All the employee perks are nice, the tickets to events, entry to venues, and various discounts. Depending on the team you work in there is also a lot of comradery and opportunity for growth, my manager took the time to schedule regular training to give us opportunities to improve our skill set in the shop too.
cons: I had some issues with the entitlement and lack of professionalism from coworkers but management was great and very approachable. Anyone would be lucky to work with them, only thing is some people take advantage of the trust and make it harder for the rest of us.

job_title: Guest Service Team Member in Lehi, UT
pros: Nice museums, nice gardens, good place to visit. ok benefits but thats all unfortunately.
cons: Too many volunteers who are retired old grumpy men with zero experience in customer service. Managers are obsolete,  volunteers make sure that THEY run the show. They also think that all your people are a bunch of morons. Also they refuse to accommodate people with disabilities, please God forbid if you think or do something outside tge box.

review_title: Fulfilling Job but with some critical cons. (COV-19 Based Review)
pros:
Work can be very rewarding, while the job can sometimes be stressful it can really make for an ideal job for a full time college student. Flexible hours, overall great co-workers and the day to day job is really quite enjoyable if you like working with kids and families. In the education department there is so many amazing opportunities for learning and growth. Without this job there is so many subjects I never would have interacted with subjects such as paleontology, geology and entomology. It's great opportunity to explore interests or just get paid to learn about stuff you would not have otherwise. In education you also get to work at all 5 Thanksgiving Point venues. Giving you really great variety in your work environment. Though will spend most your time (at least at the start) at the Butterfly Biosphere or the Museum of Natural Curiosity. 
The biggest perk for me for this job is it feels so fulfilling in comparison to other jobs available for most entry level college students. This job is refuge from soul crushing jobs in retail, the food industry and call centers.

Note: With COV-19 still being a threat it is worth noting that some of the most enjoyable parts of this job, such as guest interactions have been severely limited and have been replaced by massive cleaning schedules. Staff hiring into any of the departments that work the floor of any of the museums should expect to do a lot of cleaning until this ordeal with COV-19 is resolved. There has also been a lot of effort to cut everything but employees when it comes to budget shrinkage due to COV-19. It's clear both Senior management and internal department management care about keeping their employees jobs.
cons:
1. You will have an abundance of training (which you do get paid for) but while spending hours in training it feels like you aren't actually prepared for the job while doing it. The variety at the job is both a blessing and a curse. The con of that variety is that is hard for the department to specialize in training you for each specific venue. 
2. Communication is pretty bad, rumors are common due to lack of information from senior management and the specialist and managers in education. It's kinda of like the training's its not that communication doesn't happen, but it's just not the info that is actually important. (Though there has been improvements within the education department.)
- With COV-19 this has been both better and far worse. Employees working the floor at venues got very little information as to how and why we are opening each Venues when we opened them. Especially the children museum. Which senior management was practically radio silent on when it came to informing employees the how and why of opening that venue. Senior management orginally stated they would not open that museum until Utah was in the green, then in the middle of June during the highest spike of cases (as of 6/18/20) Utah had ever seen they decided to open with ZERO explanation as to what changed. While there have been great efforts taken to keep both guests and staff safe there is has been no communication as to what happens if/when we have a sick employee or guest pr why we opened the children's museum in the first place. 
3. Stagnant pay. Small $0.25 cent raises happened every 6-8 months if your lucky. In the education department there was an effort being made by the department management to be better about timely performance reviews and small raises in pay but due to COV-19 pay increases across the entire company have been frozen. 
4. Going off point 3 the longer you work in the education department the more responsibility you get. It is not uncommon to become a shift supervisor or lead about 6-8 months in but you will not get raise for awhile after you become a lead. Employees up and down the ladder in the department often don't feel properly compensated for the responsibilities they have. A big part of why this is the way it is because we are a non-profit but sometimes that excuse just feels hollow.
4. Due to lack of pay increases in conjunction with a dump of responsibility the longer you are in education employee burnout is a thing. The education department has had a gifted managed who has really improved the quality of things in the department but sadly employee burnout is still a problem.
5. Educations management can only do so much. We are a small cog in a larger machine. Things that would fix a lot of these cons, such a proper pay increases are solely in the hands of people above and outside the department you work in. Senior management often feels like a distant but omnipresent force. During COV-19 there has been a wave of fear and paranoia about senior management watching over our shoulders and judging our work. There are rumors that senior management is looking jobs to axe if it comes to it. (This rumor may or may not be true but due to poor communication from senior management it is hard to say.) Education is trying hard to justify it's existence in a COV-19 world and fear among higher people in the department about what senior management thinks of us trickles down and puts stress on everybody.
6. Lastly there is no paid sick leave and a COV-19 world that is straight up dangerous. There has also been no communication on what happens if/when a team member gets sick

job_title: Guest Service Team Member in Lehi, UT
pros: Lots of benefits for employees, including membership for entire family, discounts at events, restaurants, shops, etc.  Fun, happy place to work.  Feeling like you are a part of something that is good for the community.
cons: Having to work weekend and holiday shifts. Sometimes only having a job during the summer months.

review_title: People are great! Pay is atrocious.
pros: The people here are amazing! Teamwork is valued and collaborations are encouraged between departments. It has a very positive atmosphere and holds high standards.
cons: Pay is terrible. Absolutely terrible. Thanksgiving Point has a bad habit of burning out the best people they have and not paying them enough. Employees are told regularly this is because Thanksgiving Point is a non profit, and that's to be expected. As a result the turnover rate is very high. Thanksgiving Point works well as a team. But just a very underpaid and overworked team.

review_title: Fun place to work, but not many career opportunities.
pros: The people to work with are great, fun, and quirky. The small benefits, 25% off everything, free family access to venues, are nice. Lots of variety to the work load (at least in the Education Department). Management has big goals and encourages hard work.
cons: Low pay, not much opportunity for advancement--even from part-time to full-time--high turn over rate causes a lot of short staffing.

pros: Good company to work for, relaxed atmosphere and great coworkers. T
cons: he main problem is cross departmental communication. I understand that may be difficult everywhere, but at Thanksgiving Point it is a severe problem. No one ever lets other departments know anything until the last second and expect you to cover for them.

pros: Great venue.  Employees taught to be nice and give good guest service.  Generally friendly work environment for many staff.  Support for training, conferences, and employee development.
cons: Pay for many employees is limited, no retirement plan.  Traffic at exit makes 5pm commute challenging.
